trans-unit.source: Using the D20 Deck
trans-unit.target: Using the D20 Deck

trans-unit.source: Shuffle the Deck: Establish one shuffled deck as the deck that’ll be used for generating random numbers for the whole table. (You could let each PC construct a d20 deck if you have enough card decks lying around, but it takes some time to construct each deck, so the payoff may not be worth it.)
trans-unit.target: Shuffle the Deck: Establish one shuffled deck as the deck that’ll be used for generating random numbers for the whole table. (You could let each PC construct a d20 deck if you have enough card decks lying around, but it takes some time to construct each deck, so the payoff may not be worth it.)

trans-unit.source: Draw: When a character would normally roll (or you’ve decided it’s a special moment), they draw a card from the top of the shuffled deck. The card drawn is the result the character obtains.
trans-unit.target: Draw: When a character would normally roll (or you’ve decided it’s a special moment), they draw a card from the top of the shuffled deck. The card drawn is the result the character obtains.

trans-unit.source: For example, if they draw a 6 of eyes (spades), their roll is a 16. If they draw a 6 of gears (diamonds), they get a 6.
trans-unit.target: For example, if they draw a 6 of eyes (spades), their roll is a 16. If they draw a 6 of gears (diamonds), they get a 6.

trans-unit.source: Effort, Assets, Training: Characters still benefit from training, applying Effort, getting help from another character, and so on, just like normal, when they draw from the d20 deck.
trans-unit.target: Effort, Assets, Training: Characters still benefit from training, applying Effort, getting help from another character, and so on, just like normal, when they draw from the d20 deck.

trans-unit.source: Reshuffle After Every Draw: Once a given result is drawn, shuffle that card back into the deck before the next draw. It’s important to follow this step each time or probabilities will become more and more skewed.
trans-unit.target: Reshuffle After Every Draw: Once a given result is drawn, shuffle that card back into the deck before the next draw. It’s important to follow this step each time or probabilities will become more and more skewed.

trans-unit.source: Loaded Deck
trans-unit.target: Loaded Deck

trans-unit.source: If you use a d20 deck only for specific moments, consider loading the deck to create the possibility of more interesting results, both good and bad.
trans-unit.target: If you use a d20 deck only for specific moments, consider loading the deck to create the possibility of more interesting results, both good and bad.

trans-unit.source: More 1s and 20s: The easiest way to load the deck is to include another red suit Ace and another black suit 10—in the case of the Midnight deck (or standard deck), the ace of elixirs (hearts) and 10 of guns (clubs).
trans-unit.target: More 1s and 20s: The easiest way to load the deck is to include another red suit Ace and another black suit 10—in the case of the Midnight deck (or standard deck), the ace of elixirs (hearts) and 10 of guns (clubs).

trans-unit.source: Red suit Aces (no matter the suit) correspond to getting a 1 on a draw, and black suit 10s (no matter the suit) correspond to getting a natural 20 on a draw.
trans-unit.target: Red suit Aces (no matter the suit) correspond to getting a 1 on a draw, and black suit 10s (no matter the suit) correspond to getting a natural 20 on a draw.

trans-unit.source: Jackalopes/Jokers: The PCs will be surprised if they draw a jackalope (joker), especially if they think they understand how the constructed deck works. Add two jackalopes (jokers) to the loaded deck.
trans-unit.target: Jackalopes/Jokers: The PCs will be surprised if they draw a jackalope (joker), especially if they think they understand how the constructed deck works. Add two jackalopes (jokers) to the loaded deck.

trans-unit.source: If the character draws a jackalope (joker), have them draw again without shuffling the jackalope back into the deck—they can keep that card for the rest of the encounter. The second card they draw is their actual result, unless it’s another jackalope (joker), in which case, treat the two cards as if the character rolled a natural 1 and shuffle both cards back into the loaded deck.
trans-unit.target: If the character draws a jackalope (joker), have them draw again without shuffling the jackalope back into the deck—they can keep that card for the rest of the encounter. The second card they draw is their actual result, unless it’s another jackalope (joker), in which case, treat the two cards as if the character rolled a natural 1 and shuffle both cards back into the loaded deck.

trans-unit.source: If the character gets to keep a single jackalope (joker), they can choose to use it any time to take an extra turn during any given round (at which point the jackalope goes back into the loaded deck).
trans-unit.target: If the character gets to keep a single jackalope (joker), they can choose to use it any time to take an extra turn during any given round (at which point the jackalope goes back into the loaded deck).

trans-unit.source: Showdown Optional Rule
trans-unit.target: Showdown Optional Rule

trans-unit.source: Whether you’re using regular dice or a d20 deck to generate numbers, consider the following initiative option that applies specifically during a showdown between a PC and an NPC (or more than one PC against multiple NPCs). In a showdown, each participant typically has a few moments to consider their opponent and the overall situation, and in the moment of drawing their shootin’ iron, using what they notice for some sort of advantage.
trans-unit.target: Whether you’re using regular dice or a d20 deck to generate numbers, consider the following initiative option that applies specifically during a showdown between a PC and an NPC (or more than one PC against multiple NPCs). In a showdown, each participant typically has a few moments to consider their opponent and the overall situation, and in the moment of drawing their shootin’ iron, using what they notice for some sort of advantage.

trans-unit.source: Simply put, if the PC wins initiative, they can choose from one of the following benefits.
trans-unit.target: Simply put, if the PC wins initiative, they can choose from one of the following benefits.

trans-unit.source: NPC Option: NPC initiative is already determined by their level or their initiative modifier. However, if they win, they gain the benefit instead of the PC or PCs.
trans-unit.target: NPC Option: NPC initiative is already determined by their level or their initiative modifier. However, if they win, they gain the benefit instead of the PC or PCs.

trans-unit.source: Winning Initiative Benefits: The PC chooses one.
trans-unit.target: Winning Initiative Benefits: The PC chooses one.

trans-unit.source: At any point during the showdown, the character can make one extra attack.
trans-unit.target: At any point during the showdown, the character can make one extra attack.

trans-unit.source: The character adds +1 to their gun damage during the showdown.
trans-unit.target: The character adds +1 to their gun damage during the showdown.

trans-unit.source: The character gains an asset to their Speed defense during the showdown.
trans-unit.target: The character gains an asset to their Speed defense during the showdown.

trans-unit.source: At any point in the encounter, the character can treat one result as a natural 20. (If using the NPC option, an NPC hinders a PC’s roll by three steps.)
trans-unit.target: At any point in the encounter, the character can treat one result as a natural 20. (If using the NPC option, an NPC hinders a PC’s roll by three steps.)

trans-unit.source: CURSES OF THE WEIRD WEST
trans-unit.target: CURSES OF THE WEIRD WEST

trans-unit.source: If you use this optional rule, hard‑to‑dispel curses exist in your setting.
trans-unit.target: If you use this optional rule, hard‑to‑dispel curses exist in your setting.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes NPCs the PCs meet suffer from a curse, and that curse might confer upon them an unholy ability that makes it difficult for the PCs to deal with them. Other times, a PC might be cursed. Either way, PCs are probably interested in finding a way to break the curse.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes NPCs the PCs meet suffer from a curse, and that curse might confer upon them an unholy ability that makes it difficult for the PCs to deal with them. Other times, a PC might be cursed. Either way, PCs are probably interested in finding a way to break the curse.

trans-unit.source: Some curses are conferred by an individual, object, or location. For example, a deathbinder may curse a target they shoot with their soul pistol.
trans-unit.target: Some curses are conferred by an individual, object, or location. For example, a deathbinder may curse a target they shoot with their soul pistol.

trans-unit.source: Other times, evil deeds sour and rot the world, resulting in an affliction that can’t be easily remedied.
trans-unit.target: Other times, evil deeds sour and rot the world, resulting in an affliction that can’t be easily remedied.

trans-unit.source: Cursed: Some curses don’t allow the character to make a defense roll to avoid them, especially if the character takes an action they know is wrong, such as killing an innocent, burning a bar, or tearing down a religious icon revered by many. But curses conferred on the PC by an NPC’s attack should allow an appropriate defense roll. If a character is cursed, they know it when it happens—a weird feeling comes over them, all the hairs rise on their arms and neck, they feel as if “someone walked over their grave,” or something similar. However, they might not know the specific effect of the curse right away. Either way, if the character is a PC, they should get 2 XP as a GM intrusion when the curse overtakes them (1 of which they’ll give away, as normal).
trans-unit.target: Cursed: Some curses don’t allow the character to make a defense roll to avoid them, especially if the character takes an action they know is wrong, such as killing an innocent, burning a bar, or tearing down a religious icon revered by many. But curses conferred on the PC by an NPC’s attack should allow an appropriate defense roll. If a character is cursed, they know it when it happens—a weird feeling comes over them, all the hairs rise on their arms and neck, they feel as if “someone walked over their grave,” or something similar. However, they might not know the specific effect of the curse right away. Either way, if the character is a PC, they should get 2 XP as a GM intrusion when the curse overtakes them (1 of which they’ll give away, as normal).

trans-unit.source: Breaking a Curse: Breaking a curse is sometimes simple, and other times more complex.
trans-unit.target: Breaking a Curse: Breaking a curse is sometimes simple, and other times more complex.

trans-unit.source: Simple Curse Breaking: Breaking a curse could be as straightforward as smashing, killing, dispelling, demolishing, or otherwise dealing with a physical object or creature that cursed the targeted character. For instance, if cursed by a deathbinder, breaking the curse means destroying the creature permanently.
trans-unit.target: Simple Curse Breaking: Breaking a curse could be as straightforward as smashing, killing, dispelling, demolishing, or otherwise dealing with a physical object or creature that cursed the targeted character. For instance, if cursed by a deathbinder, breaking the curse means destroying the creature permanently.

trans-unit.source: Complex Curse Breaking: Some curses are more convoluted and require a specific course of action related to redressing the root transgression. Generally speaking, each solution is bespoke to the curse, and is something you can decide on based on how the curse came into being. Cursed PCs should have some means of figuring out what they must do—perhaps they could talk to an alchemist or someone else with magical skills, or succeed on a magical lore task to determine their options.
trans-unit.target: Complex Curse Breaking: Some curses are more convoluted and require a specific course of action related to redressing the root transgression. Generally speaking, each solution is bespoke to the curse, and is something you can decide on based on how the curse came into being. Cursed PCs should have some means of figuring out what they must do—perhaps they could talk to an alchemist or someone else with magical skills, or succeed on a magical lore task to determine their options.

trans-unit.source: For instance, say a PC cheats at a game of cards, which leads an NPC who loses everything to an early grave. If the PC who cheated is cursed, the curse might be that they’ll lose every game of chance they undertake afterward (which is pretty mild as these things go). As the GM, you might decide that breaking the curse requires the PC to return whatever they won off the dead NPC. Which is somewhat difficult given that the victim is no longer alive, but finding their grave and burying the objects (poker chips?) might be the first step in what needs to be done to break the curse. They might also need to summon the ghost and apologize, and perhaps even convince the ghost to forgive them.
trans-unit.target: For instance, say a PC cheats at a game of cards, which leads an NPC who loses everything to an early grave. If the PC who cheated is cursed, the curse might be that they’ll lose every game of chance they undertake afterward (which is pretty mild as these things go). As the GM, you might decide that breaking the curse requires the PC to return whatever they won off the dead NPC. Which is somewhat difficult given that the victim is no longer alive, but finding their grave and burying the objects (poker chips?) might be the first step in what needs to be done to break the curse. They might also need to summon the ghost and apologize, and perhaps even convince the ghost to forgive them.

trans-unit.source: Curses and Inciting Incident
trans-unit.target: Curses and Inciting Incident

trans-unit.source: The following table describes an array of weird west curses. Use it for inspiration for curses PCs (or NPCs the characters meet) might suffer. The effect of the curse is listed, followed by a potential inciting incident in parentheses. If the curse is conferred by an individual, object, or something outside of the control of the cursed target in your game, ignore the parenthetical.
trans-unit.target: The following table describes an array of weird west curses. Use it for inspiration for curses PCs (or NPCs the characters meet) might suffer. The effect of the curse is listed, followed by a potential inciting incident in parentheses. If the curse is conferred by an individual, object, or something outside of the control of the cursed target in your game, ignore the parenthetical.

trans-unit.source: Curse and Cause
trans-unit.target: Curse and Cause

trans-unit.source: Everyone the target kills eventually rises as a zombie and comes after target (killed someone to attain vengeance)
trans-unit.target: Everyone the target kills eventually rises as a zombie and comes after target (killed someone to attain vengeance)

trans-unit.source: Target never gets the draw—always loses initiative—in a gunfight (stray bullet killed a child)
trans-unit.target: Target never gets the draw—always loses initiative—in a gunfight (stray bullet killed a child)

trans-unit.source: Target bleeds from eyes and ears near chapels and other spiritual places, taking 1 point of ambient damage each round within long range (destroyed a religious icon)
trans-unit.target: Target bleeds from eyes and ears near chapels and other spiritual places, taking 1 point of ambient damage each round within long range (destroyed a religious icon)

trans-unit.source: Target’s footsteps burn with fire and brimstone; a huge fire risk and impossible to hide presence (burned a home with a family inside)
trans-unit.target: Target’s footsteps burn with fire and brimstone; a huge fire risk and impossible to hide presence (burned a home with a family inside)

trans-unit.source: Target compelled to challenge one person to a drinking match each night (killed/allowed deadly harm to befall a drinking companion)
trans-unit.target: Target compelled to challenge one person to a drinking match each night (killed/allowed deadly harm to befall a drinking companion)

trans-unit.source: Target must eat all food served them no matter how much or how fit it is to be eaten (accidentally/purposefully let an animal/person starve)
trans-unit.target: Target must eat all food served them no matter how much or how fit it is to be eaten (accidentally/purposefully let an animal/person starve)

trans-unit.source: Target has no face, just a blank expanse of skin (insults about another’s appearance contributed to their death)
trans-unit.target: Target has no face, just a blank expanse of skin (insults about another’s appearance contributed to their death)

trans-unit.source: Target must kill someone each day or the Devil comes for their soul (made a crossroads deal)
trans-unit.target: Target must kill someone each day or the Devil comes for their soul (made a crossroads deal)

trans-unit.source: Target falls asleep once during any fight (slept on guard duty, resulting in companion’s death)
trans-unit.target: Target falls asleep once during any fight (slept on guard duty, resulting in companion’s death)

trans-unit.source: Target’s touch freezes, causing food and drink to freeze solid, risking harm to friends, etc. (inattention/direct actions caused animal/person to die of exposure to the cold)
trans-unit.target: Target’s touch freezes, causing food and drink to freeze solid, risking harm to friends, etc. (inattention/direct actions caused animal/person to die of exposure to the cold)

trans-unit.source: Demonic bull hunts the target every night (rustled cattle)
trans-unit.target: Demonic bull hunts the target every night (rustled cattle)

trans-unit.source: Horrific nightmares degrade target’s sleep such that they are always one step down the damage track (ran instead of helping allies in a deadly fight they lost)
trans-unit.target: Horrific nightmares degrade target’s sleep such that they are always one step down the damage track (ran instead of helping allies in a deadly fight they lost)

trans-unit.source: Target is accident‑prone, suffering at least one level 5 accident a day (tripped companion died)
trans-unit.target: Target is accident‑prone, suffering at least one level 5 accident a day (tripped companion died)

trans-unit.source: Target who doesn’t sleep in a real grave does not gain the benefit of associated ten-hour recovery roll (robbed a grave)
trans-unit.target: Target who doesn’t sleep in a real grave does not gain the benefit of associated ten-hour recovery roll (robbed a grave)

trans-unit.source: Wild animals constantly find and attack target (hunted for sport, not for food and resources)
trans-unit.target: Wild animals constantly find and attack target (hunted for sport, not for food and resources)

trans-unit.source: Target’s tongue is a venomous snake that sometimes gets loose (lie led to someone’s death)
trans-unit.target: Target’s tongue is a venomous snake that sometimes gets loose (lie led to someone’s death)

trans-unit.source: Target’s touch is venomous; venom sometimes spreads to food and objects (killed an innocent spider)
trans-unit.target: Target’s touch is venomous; venom sometimes spreads to food and objects (killed an innocent spider)

trans-unit.source: Target’s reflection sometimes attacks them (vandalized/robbed a home and broke some mirrors)
trans-unit.target: Target’s reflection sometimes attacks them (vandalized/robbed a home and broke some mirrors)

trans-unit.source: Every mount the target rides quickly comes to a bad end (rode a mount to death)
trans-unit.target: Every mount the target rides quickly comes to a bad end (rode a mount to death)

trans-unit.source: Target sleepwalks, possessed by a hex gunner (stole an object that belonged to spirit)
trans-unit.target: Target sleepwalks, possessed by a hex gunner (stole an object that belonged to spirit)

trans-unit.source: Target breaks into coyote‑like howls when trying to speak (ran over a coyote with mount/wagon)
trans-unit.target: Target breaks into coyote‑like howls when trying to speak (ran over a coyote with mount/wagon)

trans-unit.source: Hanged corpses that “see” target break their ropes and attack with deadshot stats (let an innocent hang in their place)
trans-unit.target: Hanged corpses that “see” target break their ropes and attack with deadshot stats (let an innocent hang in their place)

trans-unit.source: Target only gets nutrition from human flesh and bones (forced to eat a companion to live)
trans-unit.target: Target only gets nutrition from human flesh and bones (forced to eat a companion to live)

trans-unit.source: Target’s skin becomes stiff and rusted like iron, hindering all physical tasks (killed a blacksmith)
trans-unit.target: Target’s skin becomes stiff and rusted like iron, hindering all physical tasks (killed a blacksmith)
