trans-unit.target: Character vanishes, leaving behind clothing and possessions sopping wet with rancid whiskey. Depending on the campaigning or setting, this summons an avatar of entropy into the physical world—whatever that means for your game.

trans-unit.source: *Forgeborn, queen of gears: level 4; Armor 2; two bashing attacks
trans-unit.target: *Forgeborn, queen of gears: level 4; Armor 2; two bashing attacks

trans-unit.source: SWINDLING
trans-unit.target: SWINDLING

trans-unit.source: A person with this vice is called a Shyster. They’re tricksters, but who doesn’t love a good trick? Shysters are mirage merchants who tell others what they most wish to hear. The truth is harsh—and made harsher when a lie is exposed—which is why a Shyster’s honeyed words are so potent that those who’ve been duped (call ’em marks) often refuse to believe anything other than the beautiful tapestry of fiction. The mark may even work to explain away the difference between the lie they want to believe and the cold reality of a Shyster’s grift.
trans-unit.target: A person with this vice is called a Shyster. They’re tricksters, but who doesn’t love a good trick? Shysters are mirage merchants who tell others what they most wish to hear. The truth is harsh—and made harsher when a lie is exposed—which is why a Shyster’s honeyed words are so potent that those who’ve been duped (call ’em marks) often refuse to believe anything other than the beautiful tapestry of fiction. The mark may even work to explain away the difference between the lie they want to believe and the cold reality of a Shyster’s grift.

trans-unit.source: Shyster Abilities
trans-unit.target: Shyster Abilities

trans-unit.source: A Shyster gains the following abilities, drawn from some inscrutable, invisible source.
trans-unit.target: A Shyster gains the following abilities, drawn from some inscrutable, invisible source.

trans-unit.source: Make just a couple of the indicated abilities available to the character initially, but give them one more each time they increase their connection with a low connection roll.
trans-unit.target: Make just a couple of the indicated abilities available to the character initially, but give them one more each time they increase their connection with a low connection roll.

trans-unit.source: Triggering Shyster Abilities: Some Shyster abilities require the Shyster to demonstrate a minor tell such as a wink, raised eyebrow, or quick quirk of the mouth (as part of the same action) to gain the effect, as indicated. Despite the tell, the supernatural nature of the ability means most people still don’t realize they’re being swindled.
trans-unit.target: Triggering Shyster Abilities: Some Shyster abilities require the Shyster to demonstrate a minor tell such as a wink, raised eyebrow, or quick quirk of the mouth (as part of the same action) to gain the effect, as indicated. Despite the tell, the supernatural nature of the ability means most people still don’t realize they’re being swindled.

trans-unit.source: Each time an ability is used (including enablers), the Shyster must roll 1d10 to check for a connection.
trans-unit.target: Each time an ability is used (including enablers), the Shyster must roll 1d10 to check for a connection.

trans-unit.source: Convincing Lie: For ten minutes, the Shyster gains +1 to Intellect Edge and eases Intellect defense rolls by two steps. Deception tasks are eased by two steps. Wink, raise an eyebrow, or quirk mouth (part of same action) to activate.
trans-unit.target: Convincing Lie: For ten minutes, the Shyster gains +1 to Intellect Edge and eases Intellect defense rolls by two steps. Deception tasks are eased by two steps. Wink, raise an eyebrow, or quirk mouth (part of same action) to activate.

trans-unit.source: Evade All Consequence: A mark who finally realizes that they’ve been conned by the Shyster doesn’t come looking for revenge if the Shyster doesn’t want them to. The Shyster may not have succeeded in their confidence game, especially if they didn’t use their Shyster abilities, but at least their bones remain unbroken. The specific mechanism of how all consequences are evaded varies by game and circumstance, but somehow, the invisible hand of fate tweaks the situation so the Shyster isn’t taken in or hurt. Enabler.
trans-unit.target: Evade All Consequence: A mark who finally realizes that they’ve been conned by the Shyster doesn’t come looking for revenge if the Shyster doesn’t want them to. The Shyster may not have succeeded in their confidence game, especially if they didn’t use their Shyster abilities, but at least their bones remain unbroken. The specific mechanism of how all consequences are evaded varies by game and circumstance, but somehow, the invisible hand of fate tweaks the situation so the Shyster isn’t taken in or hurt. Enabler.

trans-unit.source: Quick Thinking: If a Shyster succeeds on an Intellect defense roll for any reason, they gain an action. They can use it immediately even if they have already taken a turn (or multiple turns) in the round, but each use requires a connection roll. Enabler.
trans-unit.target: Quick Thinking: If a Shyster succeeds on an Intellect defense roll for any reason, they gain an action. They can use it immediately even if they have already taken a turn (or multiple turns) in the round, but each use requires a connection roll. Enabler.

trans-unit.source: Shyster’s Face: The Shyster’s face seems to peel away and reforms in some other guise, allowing them to hide their identity or attempt to impersonate someone else, granting two assets to any tasks involving disguise for one hour. Wink, raise an eyebrow, or quirk mouth (part of same action) to activate.
trans-unit.target: Shyster’s Face: The Shyster’s face seems to peel away and reforms in some other guise, allowing them to hide their identity or attempt to impersonate someone else, granting two assets to any tasks involving disguise for one hour. Wink, raise an eyebrow, or quirk mouth (part of same action) to activate.

trans-unit.source: Won’t Be Fooled Again: For the next day, the Shyster isn’t conned by someone else’s grift. Wink, raise an eyebrow, or quirk mouth (as an action) to activate.
trans-unit.target: Won’t Be Fooled Again: For the next day, the Shyster isn’t conned by someone else’s grift. Wink, raise an eyebrow, or quirk mouth (as an action) to activate.

trans-unit.source: Shyster Repercussions
trans-unit.target: Shyster Repercussions

trans-unit.source: A Shyster faces the following repercussions each time they roll a 1 (or higher, if previously triggered) on a connection roll. The repercussions flow from the same inhuman powers granting them their abilities. Each repercussion also increases the connection range by 1.
trans-unit.target: A Shyster faces the following repercussions each time they roll a 1 (or higher, if previously triggered) on a connection roll. The repercussions flow from the same inhuman powers granting them their abilities. Each repercussion also increases the connection range by 1.

trans-unit.source: d6
trans-unit.target: d6

trans-unit.source: Shyster Repercussions
trans-unit.target: Shyster Repercussions

trans-unit.source: Unbroken Skin. The character can’t speak or make vocal noise for one hour. During this{1}period, their mouth and vocal cords simply don’t exist; instead, the Shyster’s lower face{2}features unbroken skin without evidence of hinging jaws.
trans-unit.target: Unbroken Skin. The character can’t speak or make vocal noise for one hour. During this{1}period, their mouth and vocal cords simply don’t exist; instead, the Shyster’s lower face{2}features unbroken skin without evidence of hinging jaws.

trans-unit.source: Banned Words. Some combinations of syllables are subconsciously avoided because they{1}resonate with primordial words of power. For a moment, something the Shyster says evokes{2}such a word (level 5 effect), dealing 5 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) to themself{3}and everyone within audible range. Everyone affected suffers an optical migraine, hindering{4}sight‑based tasks for one hour
trans-unit.target: Banned Words. Some combinations of syllables are subconsciously avoided because they{1}resonate with primordial words of power. For a moment, something the Shyster says evokes{2}such a word (level 5 effect), dealing 5 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) to themself{3}and everyone within audible range. Everyone affected suffers an optical migraine, hindering{4}sight‑based tasks for one hour

trans-unit.source: Swindled by Reality. An important piece of equipment such as a favorite suit, weapon, or{1}magical artifact goes missing, apparently stolen by a master thief (but actually taken by some{2}kind of manifestation or avatar of lies).
trans-unit.target: Swindled by Reality. An important piece of equipment such as a favorite suit, weapon, or{1}magical artifact goes missing, apparently stolen by a master thief (but actually taken by some{2}kind of manifestation or avatar of lies).

trans-unit.source: The Truth Hurts. For the next few hours, any time the Shyster speaks the truth, they take{1}2 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) and everyone hears a lie determined by the GM{2}(but usually the opposite of what the Shyster meant).
trans-unit.target: The Truth Hurts. For the next few hours, any time the Shyster speaks the truth, they take{1}2 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) and everyone hears a lie determined by the GM{2}(but usually the opposite of what the Shyster meant).

trans-unit.source: Truth Spasm. For the next few hours, any time anyone within audible range of the Shyster{1}speaks the truth, a penumbra (a shadow’s edge) briefly dims the speaker’s face and they{2}suffer a horrific vision of the people, places, or things they were speaking of falling into ruin.{3}The affected character takes 2 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) each time, too.
trans-unit.target: Truth Spasm. For the next few hours, any time anyone within audible range of the Shyster{1}speaks the truth, a penumbra (a shadow’s edge) briefly dims the speaker’s face and they{2}suffer a horrific vision of the people, places, or things they were speaking of falling into ruin.{3}The affected character takes 2 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) each time, too.

trans-unit.source: Ghostly Retribution. A ghost of someone who died on account of the Shyster’s lies (or any lie{1}told by anyone) is summoned and attacks everyone.
trans-unit.target: Ghostly Retribution. A ghost of someone who died on account of the Shyster’s lies (or any lie{1}told by anyone) is summoned and attacks everyone.

trans-unit.source: Final
trans-unit.target: Final

trans-unit.source: Character vanishes, leaving behind clothing and possessions, but no hint of any identifying papers and belongings. Depending on the campaigning or setting, this summons an avatar of lies into the physical world—whatever that means for your game.
trans-unit.target: Character vanishes, leaving behind clothing and possessions, but no hint of any identifying papers and belongings. Depending on the campaigning or setting, this summons an avatar of lies into the physical world—whatever that means for your game.

trans-unit.source: THREATS AND HAZARDS OF THE WEIRD WEST
trans-unit.target: THREATS AND HAZARDS OF THE WEIRD WEST

trans-unit.source: Survey of Weird West Threats and Hazards
trans-unit.target: Survey of Weird West Threats and Hazards

trans-unit.source: If you’re looking for ideas to challenge your PCs who are between jobs or who’ve become complacent while riding into the sunset, look no further than this here table. Those spire‑like stones could be something other than strictly natural, giant scorpions are more common than most folks think, the Tomb Moon might eclipse the sun, or the characters could just discover that their mounts have been sickened by bad water.
trans-unit.target: If you’re looking for ideas to challenge your PCs who are between jobs or who’ve become complacent while riding into the sunset, look no further than this here table. Those spire‑like stones could be something other than strictly natural, giant scorpions are more common than most folks think, the Tomb Moon might eclipse the sun, or the characters could just discover that their mounts have been sickened by bad water.

trans-unit.source: Roll d00 to find the threat or hazard, or choose one from the list.
trans-unit.target: Roll d00 to find the threat or hazard, or choose one from the list.

trans-unit.source: 01–03 Scorpion Vanguard (level 4): Thousands of normal scorpions roll across the road, room, or area, dealing 1 point of damage to every creature and, on a failed Might defense roll, dazing targets (hindering their tasks) with pain for one round. A round later, a few giant scorpions follow.
trans-unit.target: 01–03 Scorpion Vanguard (level 4): Thousands of normal scorpions roll across the road, room, or area, dealing 1 point of damage to every creature and, on a failed Might defense roll, dazing targets (hindering their tasks) with pain for one round. A round later, a few giant scorpions follow.

trans-unit.source: Giant scorpion: level 3; poison stinger deals additional 3 Speed damage (ignores Armor) on failed Might defense roll
trans-unit.target: Giant scorpion: level 3; poison stinger deals additional 3 Speed damage (ignores Armor) on failed Might defense roll

trans-unit.source: 04–06 Washed-Out Passage (level 3): The stage road, train track, bridge, or other passage ahead is washed out, requiring hours of repair—assuming tools are even available.
trans-unit.target: 04–06 Washed-Out Passage (level 3): The stage road, train track, bridge, or other passage ahead is washed out, requiring hours of repair—assuming tools are even available.

trans-unit.source: 07–09 Ambush (level 5): As Washed-Out Passage, but a group of eight outlaws wait in hiding to ambush whoever finds their passage blocked; the bandits created the blockade, and can reopen the way relatively quickly.
trans-unit.target: 07–09 Ambush (level 5): As Washed-Out Passage, but a group of eight outlaws wait in hiding to ambush whoever finds their passage blocked; the bandits created the blockade, and can reopen the way relatively quickly.

trans-unit.source: Outlaws: _level 2; when working as a group of at least five, the outlaws make two level 5 long-ranged rifle attacks each round that deal 5 damage each_
trans-unit.target: Outlaws: _level 2; when working as a group of at least five, the outlaws make two level 5 long-ranged rifle attacks each round that deal 5 damage each_

trans-unit.source: 10–12 Haunted Coach (level 5): A derelict coach pulled by four skeletal horses (level 2) comes up alongside the characters. The coach is haunted by a spirit that demands the characters race it back to town (or other location); if PCs refuse, they risk becoming cursed.
trans-unit.target: 10–12 Haunted Coach (level 5): A derelict coach pulled by four skeletal horses (level 2) comes up alongside the characters. The coach is haunted by a spirit that demands the characters race it back to town (or other location); if PCs refuse, they risk becoming cursed.

trans-unit.source: 13–15 Dust devil herd (level 3): A herd of dust devils blows through a long area, taking several rounds to pass. Each round, creatures in the area take 3 points of damage on a failed Speed defense roll due to failing to escape a zigzagging dust devil; those damaged must also succeed on a Might defense roll or be blinded by dust for several rounds.
trans-unit.target: 13–15 Dust devil herd (level 3): A herd of dust devils blows through a long area, taking several rounds to pass. Each round, creatures in the area take 3 points of damage on a failed Speed defense roll due to failing to escape a zigzagging dust devil; those damaged must also succeed on a Might defense roll or be blinded by dust for several rounds.

trans-unit.source: 16–18 Nightmare Hoodoo (level 3): An irregular series of rocky spires with unlikely shapes, including boulder‑like formations balanced on thinner spires, is suffused with the undead mind of an ancient entity. Those who spend more than a few rounds within long range of the spires take 3 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) on a failed Intellect defense roll as horrific nightmares overtake their waking minds.
trans-unit.target: 16–18 Nightmare Hoodoo (level 3): An irregular series of rocky spires with unlikely shapes, including boulder‑like formations balanced on thinner spires, is suffused with the undead mind of an ancient entity. Those who spend more than a few rounds within long range of the spires take 3 points of Intellect damage (ignores Armor) on a failed Intellect defense roll as horrific nightmares overtake their waking minds.

trans-unit.source: 19–21 Nightmare Storm (level 3): An effect like that produced by a Nightmare Hoodoo, but this one moves across the landscape as a horrific psychic storm.
trans-unit.target: 19–21 Nightmare Storm (level 3): An effect like that produced by a Nightmare Hoodoo, but this one moves across the landscape as a horrific psychic storm.

trans-unit.source: 22–24 Bridge Collapse (level 4): Those traveling across a bridge, a natural arch, or a section of ground covering a yet‑undiscovered hollow must succeed on a Speed defense roll or plunge 40 feet (12 m), taking 4 points of damage and, on a failed Might defense roll, descending one step on the damage track. (The Speed defense rolls of those in a coach or train are hindered by two steps.)
trans-unit.target: 22–24 Bridge Collapse (level 4): Those traveling across a bridge, a natural arch, or a section of ground covering a yet‑undiscovered hollow must succeed on a Speed defense roll or plunge 40 feet (12 m), taking 4 points of damage and, on a failed Might defense roll, descending one step on the damage track. (The Speed defense rolls of those in a coach or train are hindered by two steps.)

trans-unit.source: 25–27 Poisoned Waters (level 3): A lake, stream, crick, or watering hole is poisoned. Drinking from it deals 3 points of damage per round for three rounds on a failed Might defense task; merely getting wet inflicts 1 point of damage per round for three rounds on a failed Might defense task. Mounts of level 3 or less that drink the water are sickened and can’t travel for a couple of days.
trans-unit.target: 25–27 Poisoned Waters (level 3): A lake, stream, crick, or watering hole is poisoned. Drinking from it deals 3 points of damage per round for three rounds on a failed Might defense task; merely getting wet inflicts 1 point of damage per round for three rounds on a failed Might defense task. Mounts of level 3 or less that drink the water are sickened and can’t travel for a couple of days.

trans-unit.source: 28–30 Saloon on Fire (level 4): Everything in the saloon (or other burning structure) takes 4 points of ambient damage each round on a failed Speed defense roll. If characters can’t escape, choking smoke in the area means they must succeed on Might defense rolls each round or suffer 2 additional points of ambient damage and lose their next action.
trans-unit.target: 28–30 Saloon on Fire (level 4): Everything in the saloon (or other burning structure) takes 4 points of ambient damage each round on a failed Speed defense roll. If characters can’t escape, choking smoke in the area means they must succeed on Might defense rolls each round or suffer 2 additional points of ambient damage and lose their next action.

trans-unit.source: 31–33 Uncanny Gnat Swarm (level 3): A swarm of undead gnats “breathed” out by a necrovore moves up to an immediate distance each round (or remains stationary) as a cloud filling an immediate area. Those in the area take 2 points of Speed damage (ignores Armor) each round from the undead bites and lose their next turn.
trans-unit.target: 31–33 Uncanny Gnat Swarm (level 3): A swarm of undead gnats “breathed” out by a necrovore moves up to an immediate distance each round (or remains stationary) as a cloud filling an immediate area. Those in the area take 2 points of Speed damage (ignores Armor) each round from the undead bites and lose their next turn.

trans-unit.source: 34–36 Waking Curse (level 4): Everyone in town wakes at midnight each night, terrified nearly to their wits’ end by the same dream of a hovering, flaming skull wearing a burning cowboy hat. Everyone, that is, but for yet another person who died of fright in their sleep. Treat as a curse affecting the town that can’t be removed until the grave of an outlaw buried somewhere in the town is found and the remains are cremated according to an alchemical procedure.
trans-unit.target: 34–36 Waking Curse (level 4): Everyone in town wakes at midnight each night, terrified nearly to their wits’ end by the same dream of a hovering, flaming skull wearing a burning cowboy hat. Everyone, that is, but for yet another person who died of fright in their sleep. Treat as a curse affecting the town that can’t be removed until the grave of an outlaw buried somewhere in the town is found and the remains are cremated according to an alchemical procedure.

trans-unit.source: 37–39 Demon Drinker (level 5): A demon wearing cowboy flesh sometimes appears in the region—usually in a saloon—and challenges a random patron to a drinking contest. The demon claims that if the selected target can match the demon shot for shot, the demon will return to Hell (or Perdition) without the patron’s soul. Sometimes the demon is killed by lawmen or others, but it always returns—it can only truly be banished if someone beats it at its whiskey‑soaked game.
trans-unit.target: 37–39 Demon Drinker (level 5): A demon wearing cowboy flesh sometimes appears in the region—usually in a saloon—and challenges a random patron to a drinking contest. The demon claims that if the selected target can match the demon shot for shot, the demon will return to Hell (or Perdition) without the patron’s soul. Sometimes the demon is killed by lawmen or others, but it always returns—it can only truly be banished if someone beats it at its whiskey‑soaked game.

trans-unit.source: 40–42 Plague of Scorpions (level 3): The shelter or campsite seems sound, until hundreds of scorpions spill from crevices, dealing 3 points of damage (ignores Armor—those little pests can get under clothing!), or 1 point even with a successful defense roll.
trans-unit.target: 40–42 Plague of Scorpions (level 3): The shelter or campsite seems sound, until hundreds of scorpions spill from crevices, dealing 3 points of damage (ignores Armor—those little pests can get under clothing!), or 1 point even with a successful defense roll.

trans-unit.source: 43–45 Lost and Hungry Settlers (level 4): A group of about eight gaunt settlers arrives in the region. They seem determined to settle in for a spell; however, they’re secretly part of a cult that believes the highest sacrament is eating human flesh (preferably that of lone cowboys and such).
trans-unit.target: 43–45 Lost and Hungry Settlers (level 4): A group of about eight gaunt settlers arrives in the region. They seem determined to settle in for a spell; however, they’re secretly part of a cult that believes the highest sacrament is eating human flesh (preferably that of lone cowboys and such).

trans-unit.source: 46–48 Stampede (level 4): A stampede of spooked pronghorns thunders through the area, streaming by for nearly a minute. Each round, other creatures in the area must succeed on a Might defense roll or be knocked down and trampled for 4 points of damage, or 1 point even with a successful defense roll.
trans-unit.target: 46–48 Stampede (level 4): A stampede of spooked pronghorns thunders through the area, streaming by for nearly a minute. Each round, other creatures in the area must succeed on a Might defense roll or be knocked down and trampled for 4 points of damage, or 1 point even with a successful defense roll.

trans-unit.source: 49–51 Poisoned Ground (level 3): Whether due to an alchemical disaster, a curse, or something horrible buried underground, something about this area drinks life, dealing 1 point of ambient damage each minute a creature remains at the epicenter, and moving PCs one step down the damage track each day they remain and fail a Might defense task.
trans-unit.target: 49–51 Poisoned Ground (level 3): Whether due to an alchemical disaster, a curse, or something horrible buried underground, something about this area drinks life, dealing 1 point of ambient damage each minute a creature remains at the epicenter, and moving PCs one step down the damage track each day they remain and fail a Might defense task.

trans-unit.source: 52–54 Uncanny Sandstorm (level 4): A disruption elsewhere causes a sandstorm dotted with greenish particles to sweep across an area that seemed perfectly safe, such as a ranch or town, dealing 1 point of ambient damage every few rounds to anyone who doesn’t take cover for the length of the storm (a few minutes).
trans-unit.target: 52–54 Uncanny Sandstorm (level 4): A disruption elsewhere causes a sandstorm dotted with greenish particles to sweep across an area that seemed perfectly safe, such as a ranch or town, dealing 1 point of ambient damage every few rounds to anyone who doesn’t take cover for the length of the storm (a few minutes).

trans-unit.source: 55–57 Toxic Stagecoach Crash (level 4): Along the trail a stagecoach is shattered against a giant, dead tree. Tendrils of dark fluid seep out of the wreckage, creating strange patterns across the ground and up the dead tree. Contact causes psychic pain (3 points of Intellect damage) and stuns characters with a series of images too fast to identify, but which render an affected target unable to take any actions until they succeed on an Intellect defense roll.
trans-unit.target: 55–57 Toxic Stagecoach Crash (level 4): Along the trail a stagecoach is shattered against a giant, dead tree. Tendrils of dark fluid seep out of the wreckage, creating strange patterns across the ground and up the dead tree. Contact causes psychic pain (3 points of Intellect damage) and stuns characters with a series of images too fast to identify, but which render an affected target unable to take any actions until they succeed on an Intellect defense roll.

trans-unit.source: 58–60 Dark Barn (level 4): A dilapidated shack, barn, or similar outbuilding on the abandoned ranch possesses a malignancy that lures in passing travelers (with strange lights, the false cry of someone in need, etc.). Once characters are inside, the malignancy traps them with a series of supernatural exploits, ranging from something as simple as a weak floor giving way beneath a character who falls 30 feet (9 m) on a failed Speed defense roll, taking 3 points of ambient damage and moving one step down the damage track, to an elaborate ploy as might be found in a haunted house.
trans-unit.target: 58–60 Dark Barn (level 4): A dilapidated shack, barn, or similar outbuilding on the abandoned ranch possesses a malignancy that lures in passing travelers (with strange lights, the false cry of someone in need, etc.). Once characters are inside, the malignancy traps them with a series of supernatural exploits, ranging from something as simple as a weak floor giving way beneath a character who falls 30 feet (9 m) on a failed Speed defense roll, taking 3 points of ambient damage and moving one step down the damage track, to an elaborate ploy as might be found in a haunted house.

trans-unit.source: 61–63 Guarded Train Trestle (level 4): The bridge is claimed by a raging locomotem that seems determined to divert any trains that speed across the tracks into the ravine below.
trans-unit.target: 61–63 Guarded Train Trestle (level 4): The bridge is claimed by a raging locomotem that seems determined to divert any trains that speed across the tracks into the ravine below.

trans-unit.source: 64–65 Prairie Fire (level 4): A lightning strike (or something more purposefully malevolent) sets the prairie ablaze! Characters and creatures that can’t escape the burning advance (which sometimes moves an immediate distance each round, but other times leaps a short or even long distance) take 4 points of damage each round they remain in the blaze. A prairie fire is hot, but usually exhausts nearby fuel within a minute, though PCs in the area are still menaced by choking smoke; they must succeed on Might defense rolls each round or suffer an additional 2 points of ambient damage and lose their next action.
trans-unit.target: 64–65 Prairie Fire (level 4): A lightning strike (or something more purposefully malevolent) sets the prairie ablaze! Characters and creatures that can’t escape the burning advance (which sometimes moves an immediate distance each round, but other times leaps a short or even long distance) take 4 points of damage each round they remain in the blaze. A prairie fire is hot, but usually exhausts nearby fuel within a minute, though PCs in the area are still menaced by choking smoke; they must succeed on Might defense rolls each round or suffer an additional 2 points of ambient damage and lose their next action.

trans-unit.source: 66–68 Necrotic Eclipse (level 5): Even for those whose business it is to track such things, the eclipse of the sun by the Tomb Moon comes as a surprise. During the four-minute period of complete darkness when only the sun’s fiery crown is visible, a scourge of necrovores attacks the town unlucky enough to lie in the path of totality.
trans-unit.target: 66–68 Necrotic Eclipse (level 5): Even for those whose business it is to track such things, the eclipse of the sun by the Tomb Moon comes as a surprise. During the four-minute period of complete darkness when only the sun’s fiery crown is visible, a scourge of necrovores attacks the town unlucky enough to lie in the path of totality.

trans-unit.source: 69–72 Ghostnado (level 5): Ghosts generate a vortex of necrotic energy, creating a rotating column of undeath that draws in nearby life, resulting in a powerful whirlwind of extinction. The vortex persists for about a minute, during which it may move an immediate distance in a random direction, jump a short or long distance, or stay still during a round. On a failed Might defense roll, any living thing touched by the ghostnado suffers 5 points of Speed damage (ignores Armor) from their life being sucked away. PCs must also succeed on a Speed defense roll or be pulled up into the ghostnado, where they automatically suffer damage each round until either they escape or the vortex dissipates.
trans-unit.target: 69–72 Ghostnado (level 5): Ghosts generate a vortex of necrotic energy, creating a rotating column of undeath that draws in nearby life, resulting in a powerful whirlwind of extinction. The vortex persists for about a minute, during which it may move an immediate distance in a random direction, jump a short or long distance, or stay still during a round. On a failed Might defense roll, any living thing touched by the ghostnado suffers 5 points of Speed damage (ignores Armor) from their life being sucked away. PCs must also succeed on a Speed defense roll or be pulled up into the ghostnado, where they automatically suffer damage each round until either they escape or the vortex dissipates.

trans-unit.source: 73–76 When It Rains, It Floods (level 4): Torrential rains in the mountains cause a serious flood in the area. Failed Speed defense rolls mean the rushing waters envelop characters in low‑lying areas, inflicting 4 points of Speed damage (a combination of the tumult and the character desperately trying to keep their head above water) and moving them a short distance in the direction of the water’s flow. This happens each round until an affected character can pull themself out of the water. If that wasn’t bad enough, sometimes there are zombies in the water.
trans-unit.target: 73–76 When It Rains, It Floods (level 4): Torrential rains in the mountains cause a serious flood in the area. Failed Speed defense rolls mean the rushing waters envelop characters in low‑lying areas, inflicting 4 points of Speed damage (a combination of the tumult and the character desperately trying to keep their head above water) and moving them a short distance in the direction of the water’s flow. This happens each round until an affected character can pull themself out of the water. If that wasn’t bad enough, sometimes there are zombies in the water.

trans-unit.source: 77–79 Alchemical Accident (level 5): An alchemist set up an out‑of‑the‑way lab to run dangerous experiments. Those who investigate the lonely structure set off an experiment gone wrong, which implodes in a violent, violet blast dealing 5 points of damage to everything in short range.
trans-unit.target: 77–79 Alchemical Accident (level 5): An alchemist set up an out‑of‑the‑way lab to run dangerous experiments. Those who investigate the lonely structure set off an experiment gone wrong, which implodes in a violent, violet blast dealing 5 points of damage to everything in short range.

trans-unit.source: 80–82 Conscription (level 4): A broken cavalry of twelve soldiers and their captain claim they represent the government (possibly one the PCs have heard of, possibly not). The captain explains the characters have been conscripted into the army, and now must follow the soldiers to the war front. PCs who resist are attacked as deserters.
trans-unit.target: 80–82 Conscription (level 4): A broken cavalry of twelve soldiers and their captain claim they represent the government (possibly one the PCs have heard of, possibly not). The captain explains the characters have been conscripted into the army, and now must follow the soldiers to the war front. PCs who resist are attacked as deserters.

trans-unit.source: Soldier: _level 2, attacks and damage while on horseback as level 3_
trans-unit.target: Soldier: _level 2, attacks and damage while on horseback as level 3_

trans-unit.source: Captain: _level 4; health 25_
trans-unit.target: Captain: _level 4; health 25_

trans-unit.source: 83–86 Unquiet Crops (level 3): Something’s gotten into the corn. The kernels burst from their husks like bullets. Creatures within short range are attacked two or three times each round as kernels whistle past their eyes or strike home, dealing 3 points of damage per strike.
trans-unit.target: 83–86 Unquiet Crops (level 3): Something’s gotten into the corn. The kernels burst from their husks like bullets. Creatures within short range are attacked two or three times each round as kernels whistle past their eyes or strike home, dealing 3 points of damage per strike.

trans-unit.source: 87–89 Mine Collapse (level 4): Who knew the whole area was riddled with mineshafts? The ground slumps, sending all creatures in the area who fail a Might defense roll to hold on to something solid into a subterranean region. Affected creatures take 4 points of damage in the fall, and then are potentially trapped underground in a warren of tunnels until they can find a way out. Which ain’t great, but sometimes there are nightcrawlers in the tunnels.
trans-unit.target: 87–89 Mine Collapse (level 4): Who knew the whole area was riddled with mineshafts? The ground slumps, sending all creatures in the area who fail a Might defense roll to hold on to something solid into a subterranean region. Affected creatures take 4 points of damage in the fall, and then are potentially trapped underground in a warren of tunnels until they can find a way out. Which ain’t great, but sometimes there are nightcrawlers in the tunnels.

trans-unit.source: 90–93 Alien Base (level 6): A lone alien known as an enthraller has a secret base in the badlands; the alien is using mind‑controlled outlaws to kidnap targets for it to study.
trans-unit.target: 90–93 Alien Base (level 6): A lone alien known as an enthraller has a secret base in the badlands; the alien is using mind‑controlled outlaws to kidnap targets for it to study.

trans-unit.source: 94–97 Hellmound (level 6): Like a human‑sized anthill, except the mound is filled with demons.
trans-unit.target: 94–97 Hellmound (level 6): Like a human‑sized anthill, except the mound is filled with demons.

trans-unit.source: 98–99 Uncanny Blizzard (level 4): Blinding snow and supernaturally freezing conditions burst across the region. Those caught without cover take 4 points of ambient damage from the initial blast of cold and are thereafter subject to dangers associated with it being too cold.
trans-unit.target: 98–99 Uncanny Blizzard (level 4): Blinding snow and supernaturally freezing conditions burst across the region. Those caught without cover take 4 points of ambient damage from the initial blast of cold and are thereafter subject to dangers associated with it being too cold.

trans-unit.source: 00 Alchemical War Machine (level 9): A massive machine the size of a small town on great steel legs stirs in the desert.
trans-unit.target: 00 Alchemical War Machine (level 9): A massive machine the size of a small town on great steel legs stirs in the desert.

trans-unit.source: Equipment
trans-unit.target: Equipment

trans-unit.source: Currency
trans-unit.target: Currency

trans-unit.source: All kinds of currencies could be used simultaneously in your weird west game on account of the scarcity of officially issued coins and paper money. Here are some options for your consideration.
trans-unit.target: All kinds of currencies could be used simultaneously in your weird west game on account of the scarcity of officially issued coins and paper money. Here are some options for your consideration.

trans-unit.source: Dollars
trans-unit.target: Dollars

trans-unit.source: In a weird west world inspired by real world history, you might decide to adopt the dollar. Dollars are mostly circulated as coins of various denominations. Paper money is also printed, though not as widely circulated.
trans-unit.target: In a weird west world inspired by real world history, you might decide to adopt the dollar. Dollars are mostly circulated as coins of various denominations. Paper money is also printed, though not as widely circulated.

trans-unit.source: The Cypher System Rulebook uses price categories as an abstract way of defining equipment prices. If you want to use dollars instead of categories in the CSR, use the following equivalencies as a rough guideline. As you’ll note, dollars go a lot further in a weird west (and historical) setting than in a modern game.
trans-unit.target: The Cypher System Rulebook uses price categories as an abstract way of defining equipment prices. If you want to use dollars instead of categories in the CSR, use the following equivalencies as a rough guideline. As you’ll note, dollars go a lot further in a weird west (and historical) setting than in a modern game.

trans-unit.source: Category
trans-unit.target: Category

trans-unit.source: Dollar Value
trans-unit.target: Dollar Value

trans-unit.source: Inexpensive
trans-unit.target: Inexpensive

trans-unit.source: Up to $1
trans-unit.target: Up to $1

trans-unit.source: Moderate
trans-unit.target: Moderate

trans-unit.source: Expensive
trans-unit.target: Expensive

trans-unit.source: Very expensive
trans-unit.target: Very expensive

trans-unit.source: Exorbitant
trans-unit.target: Exorbitant

trans-unit.source: For items between these dollar ranges, use multiples of the cheaper category, or require multiples to count as the pricier category. For example, a service worth $50 is between the moderate and expensive categories, so it’s worth a few moderate items, or two services like it are worth one expensive item.
trans-unit.target: For items between these dollar ranges, use multiples of the cheaper category, or require multiples to count as the pricier category. For example, a service worth $50 is between the moderate and expensive categories, so it’s worth a few moderate items, or two services like it are worth one expensive item.

trans-unit.source: Gold Dust and Nuggets
trans-unit.target: Gold Dust and Nuggets

trans-unit.source: Gold could be a highly valued currency in your setting, though if you’re looking for something weirder, use stardust instead (or in addition). Pouches or vials of gold dust weighing no more than half an ounce (14 g) are equal to an inexpensive item, bags of gold dust weighing no more than 5 ounces (140 g) are equal to a moderately priced item, and so on. Even if not recognized as official currency, small pouches of gold dust could be used for barter.
trans-unit.target: Gold could be a highly valued currency in your setting, though if you’re looking for something weirder, use stardust instead (or in addition). Pouches or vials of gold dust weighing no more than half an ounce (14 g) are equal to an inexpensive item, bags of gold dust weighing no more than 5 ounces (140 g) are equal to a moderately priced item, and so on. Even if not recognized as official currency, small pouches of gold dust could be used for barter.

trans-unit.source: Barter
trans-unit.target: Barter

trans-unit.source: In especially remote regions, folks tend to trade goods and services directly with each other, even when other currency is also accepted. Equating all the ways someone might barter—in which haggling is expected—directly to price categories is an approximate art.
trans-unit.target: In especially remote regions, folks tend to trade goods and services directly with each other, even when other currency is also accepted. Equating all the ways someone might barter—in which haggling is expected—directly to price categories is an approximate art.

trans-unit.source: You can use the equipment list price categories to help you decide how much something is worth when bartered for. For example, the equipment list reveals that both a candle and a simple meal are inexpensive items, meaning one could be bartered for the other.
trans-unit.target: You can use the equipment list price categories to help you decide how much something is worth when bartered for. For example, the equipment list reveals that both a candle and a simple meal are inexpensive items, meaning one could be bartered for the other.

trans-unit.source: Ammunition
trans-unit.target: Ammunition

trans-unit.source: If nothing else, ammunition is valuable. It could even be one form of trade used in your weird west game. If so, fussing about what bullet can be used in what kind of gun isn’t as important as it being clear that ammunition is unfired and potentially live.
trans-unit.target: If nothing else, ammunition is valuable. It could even be one form of trade used in your weird west game. If so, fussing about what bullet can be used in what kind of gun isn’t as important as it being clear that ammunition is unfired and potentially live.

trans-unit.source: Use the following guidelines to equate price categories to rounds of ammunition.
trans-unit.target: Use the following guidelines to equate price categories to rounds of ammunition.

trans-unit.source: Scrip and Private Tokens
trans-unit.target: Scrip and Private Tokens

trans-unit.source: Your weird west setting might include one or more vouchers or tokens issued by organized groups like railroad companies, banks, and even individual saloons to pay those they do business with. Such scrip may or may not have value outside the area where it was issued, depending on your setting.
trans-unit.target: Your weird west setting might include one or more vouchers or tokens issued by organized groups like railroad companies, banks, and even individual saloons to pay those they do business with. Such scrip may or may not have value outside the area where it was issued, depending on your setting.

trans-unit.source: For example, the Trail’s End Cantina, a local saloon in Midnight, offers smoothed coins (larger legal coins cut into quarters), each stamped with a horseshoe symbol. These are given to high rollers at the saloon’s card tables. These so-called “irons” get passed around, are bought and sold, and are generally considered to be worth a moderately priced item in the community, and an inexpensive item elsewhere.
trans-unit.target: For example, the Trail’s End Cantina, a local saloon in Midnight, offers smoothed coins (larger legal coins cut into quarters), each stamped with a horseshoe symbol. These are given to high rollers at the saloon’s card tables. These so-called “irons” get passed around, are bought and sold, and are generally considered to be worth a moderately priced item in the community, and an inexpensive item elsewhere.

trans-unit.source: Other notes and documents that retain value almost anywhere include land deeds (especially if they’re transferrable) and stock certificates. However, stock certificates may not be appropriate to your setting if there isn’t a “national” stock market where shares are bought and sold.
trans-unit.target: Other notes and documents that retain value almost anywhere include land deeds (especially if they’re transferrable) and stock certificates. However, stock certificates may not be appropriate to your setting if there isn’t a “national” stock market where shares are bought and sold.

trans-unit.source: Additional Weird West Equipment
trans-unit.target: Additional Weird West Equipment

trans-unit.source: Many weird west games assume a technological level equivalent to the American West in the 1800s, with the possibility of magical and/or steampunk artifacts thrown into the mix. This assumption holds for the equipment list provided here. PCs can use it to choose their starting equipment, or browse when they enter a general store.
trans-unit.target: Many weird west games assume a technological level equivalent to the American West in the 1800s, with the possibility of magical and/or steampunk artifacts thrown into the mix. This assumption holds for the equipment list provided here. PCs can use it to choose their starting equipment, or browse when they enter a general store.

trans-unit.source: Sci-fi? However, your weird west campaign might take place in the future or on another planet settled via spaceflight, which could include a combination of the items in this chapter plus some items from the Additional Science Fiction Equipment list.

trans-unit.source: Reloading Guns in the Weird West
trans-unit.target: Reloading Guns in the Weird West

trans-unit.source: Six‑shooters and other firearms in your setting might be more primitive than modern firearms and require extra time to reload—or not. Maybe the PCs are just that good, in which case, revolvers and other guns popular in your setting can be reloaded as part of another action. Alternatively, you could require that PCs use an action to reload six bullets into the chamber of the shootin’ iron (unless they have the Reload ability). If you don’t want to burden PCs with keeping track of how many bullets remain in the cylinders of their revolvers, an easy way to determine if a character’s six‑shooter is empty after any given turn is to use depletion; a typical six‑shooter has a depletion of 1 in 1d6.
trans-unit.target: Six‑shooters and other firearms in your setting might be more primitive than modern firearms and require extra time to reload—or not. Maybe the PCs are just that good, in which case, revolvers and other guns popular in your setting can be reloaded as part of another action. Alternatively, you could require that PCs use an action to reload six bullets into the chamber of the shootin’ iron (unless they have the Reload ability). If you don’t want to burden PCs with keeping track of how many bullets remain in the cylinders of their revolvers, an easy way to determine if a character’s six‑shooter is empty after any given turn is to use depletion; a typical six‑shooter has a depletion of 1 in 1d6.

trans-unit.source: Cyphers
trans-unit.target: Cyphers

trans-unit.source: Subtle Cyphers
trans-unit.target: Subtle Cyphers

trans-unit.source: Subtle cyphers are appropriate as an adjunct to weird west games that have at least a passing similarity to historical reality.
trans-unit.target: Subtle cyphers are appropriate as an adjunct to weird west games that have at least a passing similarity to historical reality.

trans-unit.source: That said, weird west games—with their connection to magic and/or sci‑fi technology—have a lot of room to include thematically appropriate manifest cyphers (as shown by the examples provided later in this chapter). If you include manifest cyphers, remember that the Cypher System rules assume players have regular opportunities to regain cyphers after using the ones they have. Out in the badlands, deserts, or prairielands where weird west adventurers often find themselves, manifest cyphers might be harder to obtain. Letting subtle cyphers fill in the gaps during periods when PCs don’t find any manifest ones is a good idea.
trans-unit.target: That said, weird west games—with their connection to magic and/or sci‑fi technology—have a lot of room to include thematically appropriate manifest cyphers (as shown by the examples provided later in this chapter). If you include manifest cyphers, remember that the Cypher System rules assume players have regular opportunities to regain cyphers after using the ones they have. Out in the badlands, deserts, or prairielands where weird west adventurers often find themselves, manifest cyphers might be harder to obtain. Letting subtle cyphers fill in the gaps during periods when PCs don’t find any manifest ones is a good idea.

trans-unit.source: Manifest Cyphers
trans-unit.target: Manifest Cyphers

trans-unit.source: Manifest cyphers in a weird west game could be the product of some oddity of your particular setting, such as alien invaders. However, the primary assumption is that manifest weird west cyphers are created by alchemists, sorcerers, demons, and the like.
trans-unit.target: Manifest cyphers in a weird west game could be the product of some oddity of your particular setting, such as alien invaders. However, the primary assumption is that manifest weird west cyphers are created by alchemists, sorcerers, demons, and the like.

trans-unit.source: Alien Manifest Cyphers
trans-unit.target: Alien Manifest Cyphers

trans-unit.source: In a weird west setting enduring an ongoing alien invasion, encroaching alien outposts, crashed starfighters, and the rare alien conscientious objector who feels bad about conquering the place could all be sources of uncanny items. Given their off‑world manufacture, these manifest cyphers are probably nearly inscrutable, but PCs are able to get a single use out of them, even if it’s not the use the aliens had in mind.
trans-unit.target: In a weird west setting enduring an ongoing alien invasion, encroaching alien outposts, crashed starfighters, and the rare alien conscientious objector who feels bad about conquering the place could all be sources of uncanny items. Given their off‑world manufacture, these manifest cyphers are probably nearly inscrutable, but PCs are able to get a single use out of them, even if it’s not the use the aliens had in mind.

trans-unit.source: Alchemical Manifest Cyphers
trans-unit.target: Alchemical Manifest Cyphers

trans-unit.source: Alchemy is usually attributed to alchemists, while sorcery is attributed to demons and/or those who learned their magic from a Hellish source. But sometimes alchemists create items of such dire consequence that demons would be happy to take the credit.
trans-unit.target: Alchemy is usually attributed to alchemists, while sorcery is attributed to demons and/or those who learned their magic from a Hellish source. But sometimes alchemists create items of such dire consequence that demons would be happy to take the credit.

trans-unit.source: The most prominent alchemical manifest cyphers are alchemical rounds and slugs— ammunition for pistols, rifles, and shotguns.
trans-unit.target: The most prominent alchemical manifest cyphers are alchemical rounds and slugs— ammunition for pistols, rifles, and shotguns.

trans-unit.source: A handful of alchemists sell their rounds and slugs to interested buyers for an expensive cost, or very expensive for level 5 and higher alchemical rounds and slugs.
trans-unit.target: A handful of alchemists sell their rounds and slugs to interested buyers for an expensive cost, or very expensive for level 5 and higher alchemical rounds and slugs.

trans-unit.source: Alchemical rounds operate using a few special rules, as follow.
trans-unit.target: Alchemical rounds operate using a few special rules, as follow.

trans-unit.source: Form of Alchemical Rounds: Alchemical rounds—such as a banishing round or an asphyxiation round—are alchemical manifest cyphers in the form of bullets or shells that visibly glow in dim light. The alchemist who made a given bullet or shell usually inscribes it with their mark—a symbol, their initials, and so on.
trans-unit.target: Form of Alchemical Rounds: Alchemical rounds—such as a banishing round or an asphyxiation round—are alchemical manifest cyphers in the form of bullets or shells that visibly glow in dim light. The alchemist who made a given bullet or shell usually inscribes it with their mark—a symbol, their initials, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Loading Alchemical Rounds: Alchemical rounds use whatever reloading rules are in use in the setting. So, if the reloading rules are such that reloading—when a gunfighter pulls the bullet from a bandolier or cartridge belt and slips it into the chamber—is part of another action, a gunfighter with an alchemical round available may simply declare any given shot they attempt is using that round. Otherwise, it takes an action to load an alchemical round into the chamber. However, the continuing effect an alchemical round confers lessens the sting of the action spent reloading.
trans-unit.target: Loading Alchemical Rounds: Alchemical rounds use whatever reloading rules are in use in the setting. So, if the reloading rules are such that reloading—when a gunfighter pulls the bullet from a bandolier or cartridge belt and slips it into the chamber—is part of another action, a gunfighter with an alchemical round available may simply declare any given shot they attempt is using that round. Otherwise, it takes an action to load an alchemical round into the chamber. However, the continuing effect an alchemical round confers lessens the sting of the action spent reloading.

trans-unit.source: Continuing Effect of Alchemical Round Attacks: When an alchemical round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made with that gun gain the same benefit for the next minute (as indicated in each alchemical round entry). For example, if a character fires a banishing round, every attack they make with the same gun for the next minute is also considered a banishing round, regardless of whether the first attack hits or misses. Some alchemical bullets do not infuse the gun they’re fired from, as indicated by name—they’re referred to as slugs instead of rounds—and in the description. For example, dark slugs and thunder slugs do not infuse the gun, but instead create a lasting effect in an adjacent area. If a second alchemical round is fired from the same gun while an earlier infusion effect remains active, refer to the Alchemical Round Fusion Effect table.
trans-unit.target: Continuing Effect of Alchemical Round Attacks: When an alchemical round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made with that gun gain the same benefit for the next minute (as indicated in each alchemical round entry). For example, if a character fires a banishing round, every attack they make with the same gun for the next minute is also considered a banishing round, regardless of whether the first attack hits or misses. Some alchemical bullets do not infuse the gun they’re fired from, as indicated by name—they’re referred to as slugs instead of rounds—and in the description. For example, dark slugs and thunder slugs do not infuse the gun, but instead create a lasting effect in an adjacent area. If a second alchemical round is fired from the same gun while an earlier infusion effect remains active, refer to the Alchemical Round Fusion Effect table.

trans-unit.source: Answering Slug
trans-unit.target: Answering Slug

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6

trans-unit.source: Form: “RETORT” scribed on bullet case
trans-unit.target: Form: “RETORT” scribed on bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: A successful attack with an answering slug damages a target normally. In addition, for the next minute, any time another creature attacks the shooter with a ranged attack, the shooter can make an immediate extra attack against that creature using the same gun, ignoring reloading restrictions (if any apply). While the effect lasts, the shooter can make a number of additional immediate “answering” attacks equal to the cypher’s level (in addition to making their normal attack for the round).
trans-unit.target: Effect: A successful attack with an answering slug damages a target normally. In addition, for the next minute, any time another creature attacks the shooter with a ranged attack, the shooter can make an immediate extra attack against that creature using the same gun, ignoring reloading restrictions (if any apply). While the effect lasts, the shooter can make a number of additional immediate “answering” attacks equal to the cypher’s level (in addition to making their normal attack for the round).

trans-unit.source: Asphyxiation Round
trans-unit.target: Asphyxiation Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 1
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 1

trans-unit.source: Form: Blowing wind image scribed on bullet case
trans-unit.target: Form: Blowing wind image scribed on bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack damages a target normally. If the damaged target is a living creature that needs to breathe, the target becomes short of breath, hindering all their tasks for a number of rounds equal to the cypher’s level. If the same target is struck and damaged again within that minute with another asphyxiation round, they are stunned as air is alchemically forced from their lungs and blood. Unless at least one asphyxiation round stuck in their flesh is removed from a stunned target’s flesh with a successful level 4 healing task, the stunned target asphyxiates and dies at the end of the minute the target first became short of breath.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack damages a target normally. If the damaged target is a living creature that needs to breathe, the target becomes short of breath, hindering all their tasks for a number of rounds equal to the cypher’s level. If the same target is struck and damaged again within that minute with another asphyxiation round, they are stunned as air is alchemically forced from their lungs and blood. Unless at least one asphyxiation round stuck in their flesh is removed from a stunned target’s flesh with a successful level 4 healing task, the stunned target asphyxiates and dies at the end of the minute the target first became short of breath.

trans-unit.source: Banishing Round
trans-unit.target: Banishing Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 1
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 1

trans-unit.source: Form: “EXCLUDE LIFE” scribed on bullet case
trans-unit.target: Form: “EXCLUDE LIFE” scribed on bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. Undead, ghosts, cursed beasts, and other supernatural targets take full damage from this attack (if successful). Affected targets gain no benefit from Armor, intangibility, or other protection, and lose any automatic healing ability for a number of minutes equal to this cypher’s level. Normal targets with protective alchemical spells similarly lose that protection. If the cypher’s level is 6 or higher, successful attacks deal +1 point of damage.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. Undead, ghosts, cursed beasts, and other supernatural targets take full damage from this attack (if successful). Affected targets gain no benefit from Armor, intangibility, or other protection, and lose any automatic healing ability for a number of minutes equal to this cypher’s level. Normal targets with protective alchemical spells similarly lose that protection. If the cypher’s level is 6 or higher, successful attacks deal +1 point of damage.

trans-unit.source: Dark Slug
trans-unit.target: Dark Slug

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 1
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 1

trans-unit.source: Form: Round is dark as the night sky
trans-unit.target: Form: Round is dark as the night sky

trans-unit.source: Effect: Firing the slug creates a region of absolute darkness from which no sound emerges. The region fills an adjacent short area (or long area if the cypher is level 5 or higher) and lasts for about a minute.
trans-unit.target: Effect: Firing the slug creates a region of absolute darkness from which no sound emerges. The region fills an adjacent short area (or long area if the cypher is level 5 or higher) and lasts for about a minute.

trans-unit.source: Any creature whose level is less than the cypher’s that enters (or begins their turn in) the area can see nothing (even if they can normally see in darkness), and any light source of lower level than the cypher’s that is brought into or begins a turn in the darkness is deactivated. While the cypher is in effect, successfully escaping the darkness is hindered by four steps.
trans-unit.target: Any creature whose level is less than the cypher’s that enters (or begins their turn in) the area can see nothing (even if they can normally see in darkness), and any light source of lower level than the cypher’s that is brought into or begins a turn in the darkness is deactivated. While the cypher is in effect, successfully escaping the darkness is hindered by four steps.

trans-unit.source: Entombing Round
trans-unit.target: Entombing Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 2
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 2

trans-unit.source: Form: Coffin image scribed on bullet case
trans-unit.target: Form: Coffin image scribed on bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack with an entombing round doesn’t damage the target; instead, a target up to human size is held in place, still able to take actions but unable to move or leave the spot for one minute or until they escape with a successful Might‑based roll. (NPCs whose level is higher than the round’s break free if they spend their next turn escaping.)
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack with an entombing round doesn’t damage the target; instead, a target up to human size is held in place, still able to take actions but unable to move or leave the spot for one minute or until they escape with a successful Might‑based roll. (NPCs whose level is higher than the round’s break free if they spend their next turn escaping.)

trans-unit.source: If the same target is hit again with an entombing round while still held immobile, they are enveloped in an expanding mass that takes the shape of a closed, secured wooden casket whose level is equal to the round’s level. A third successful attack against an affected target causes the casket to sink 6 feet (2 m) into the earth, buried beneath a pile of loose soil.
trans-unit.target: If the same target is hit again with an entombing round while still held immobile, they are enveloped in an expanding mass that takes the shape of a closed, secured wooden casket whose level is equal to the round’s level. A third successful attack against an affected target causes the casket to sink 6 feet (2 m) into the earth, buried beneath a pile of loose soil.

trans-unit.source: A trapped target is held within the casket until the gunfighter releases them, the casket is destroyed, the target breaks free, or midnight arrives, at which time the casket dissolves to dust. If the target’s casket is buried when their casket dissolves, they have until their breath expires (a minute or so) to dig their way to the surface (a level 5 task) or remain buried.
trans-unit.target: A trapped target is held within the casket until the gunfighter releases them, the casket is destroyed, the target breaks free, or midnight arrives, at which time the casket dissolves to dust. If the target’s casket is buried when their casket dissolves, they have until their breath expires (a minute or so) to dig their way to the surface (a level 5 task) or remain buried.

trans-unit.source: Wooden casket: level equal to entombing round cypher; dissolves at midnight
trans-unit.target: Wooden casket: level equal to entombing round cypher; dissolves at midnight

trans-unit.source: Exorcism Round
trans-unit.target: Exorcism Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 4
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 4

trans-unit.source: Form: Broken horn image scribed on bullet case
trans-unit.target: Form: Broken horn image scribed on bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack with an exorcism round damages a target normally. In addition, ghosts and demons (whether immaterial or wearing someone else’s flesh)—as well as other creatures strongly tied to an alternate realm—hit by this attack are exorcised if their level is less than or equal to the cypher’s level. An exorcised creature disappears and is unable to remanifest physically in the same area or realm for at least one day.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack with an exorcism round damages a target normally. In addition, ghosts and demons (whether immaterial or wearing someone else’s flesh)—as well as other creatures strongly tied to an alternate realm—hit by this attack are exorcised if their level is less than or equal to the cypher’s level. An exorcised creature disappears and is unable to remanifest physically in the same area or realm for at least one day.

trans-unit.source: This attack is potentially as effective against a target being possessed by a ghost or demon, ending the possession, though the host is also damaged by the bullet.
trans-unit.target: This attack is potentially as effective against a target being possessed by a ghost or demon, ending the possession, though the host is also damaged by the bullet.

trans-unit.source: Exsanguinating Round
trans-unit.target: Exsanguinating Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 +1
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 +1

trans-unit.source: Form: Red blood smears bullet case
trans-unit.target: Form: Red blood smears bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. The target takes damage normally. If the target is living and has blood, it begins bleeding for 1 point of damage per round for one minute. Additional successful attacks increase the damage on a one‑per‑one‑basis, and extend the period of effect.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. The target takes damage normally. If the target is living and has blood, it begins bleeding for 1 point of damage per round for one minute. Additional successful attacks increase the damage on a one‑per‑one‑basis, and extend the period of effect.

trans-unit.source: The expelled blood forms a mystical rivulet that connects the shooter with the bleeding target. If the target dies, the shooter gains an immediate free recovery roll (or regains 10 health if an NPC).
trans-unit.target: The expelled blood forms a mystical rivulet that connects the shooter with the bleeding target. If the target dies, the shooter gains an immediate free recovery roll (or regains 10 health if an NPC).

trans-unit.source: If the shooter who fired the round is a vampire and their bleeding target is killed, the vampire is completely healed and gains the benefit of having just drank a victim’s blood to their fill.
trans-unit.target: If the shooter who fired the round is a vampire and their bleeding target is killed, the vampire is completely healed and gains the benefit of having just drank a victim’s blood to their fill.

trans-unit.source: Flaying Round
trans-unit.target: Flaying Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6

trans-unit.source: Form: Bullet case seems made of skin
trans-unit.target: Form: Bullet case seems made of skin

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack damages a target normally. The target’s skin/fur/outer layer begins to peel away as if they’d gained the attention of an invisible flensing blade, hindering their tasks for one minute per cypher level. The second time a target is struck and damaged with a flaying round within a minute of first being struck, larger sections of skin peel away, hindering them by two steps. Each three steps of hindrance gained also moves the target one step down the damage track.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. A successful attack damages a target normally. The target’s skin/fur/outer layer begins to peel away as if they’d gained the attention of an invisible flensing blade, hindering their tasks for one minute per cypher level. The second time a target is struck and damaged with a flaying round within a minute of first being struck, larger sections of skin peel away, hindering them by two steps. Each three steps of hindrance gained also moves the target one step down the damage track.

trans-unit.target: Ghost Round

trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6

trans-unit.source: Form: Round appears ghostly, translucent, not quite real
trans-unit.target: Form: Round appears ghostly, translucent, not quite real

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. Unliving targets (undead, forgeborn, elementals, objects, etc.) take damage normally from a ghost round attack, or normal damage +2 if the cypher is level 5 or higher. However, the ghost round ignores living flesh, passing through it like . . . a ghost.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. Unliving targets (undead, forgeborn, elementals, objects, etc.) take damage normally from a ghost round attack, or normal damage +2 if the cypher is level 5 or higher. trans-unit.source: Glacier Slug
trans-unit.target: Glacier Slug

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 1
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 1

trans-unit.source: Form: Bullet case seems made of ice
trans-unit.target: Form: Bullet case seems made of ice

trans-unit.source: Effect: A successful attack deals damage equal to the cypher’s level and freezes the target (rendering them helpless) for a number of minutes equal to the cypher’s level. A PC who succeeds on a Might‑based roll as their action can thaw early (an affected NPC whose level is higher than the cypher’s can use their next turn to break free). On a miss, the target still takes 2 points of damage from the cold (3 points if the cypher is level 5 or higher).
trans-unit.target: Effect: A successful attack deals damage equal to the cypher’s level and freezes the target (rendering them helpless) for a number of minutes equal to the cypher’s level. A PC who succeeds on a Might‑based roll as their action can thaw early (an affected NPC whose level is higher than the cypher’s can use their next turn to break free). On a miss, the target still takes 2 points of damage from the cold (3 points if the cypher is level 5 or higher).

trans-unit.source: Gunlantern Slug
trans-unit.target: Gunlantern Slug

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 1
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 1

trans-unit.source: Form: Bullet case glows dim as a candle
trans-unit.target: Form: Bullet case glows dim as a candle

trans-unit.source: Effect: Firing the slug (either as an attack or into the air) causes the gun to emit a beam of light for three hours per cypher level. The beam brightly illuminates an immediate area the gun wielder points their gun at within long range.
trans-unit.target: Effect: Firing the slug (either as an attack or into the air) causes the gun to emit a beam of light for three hours per cypher level. The beam brightly illuminates an immediate area the gun wielder points their gun at within long range.

trans-unit.source: If the wielder points their light into a region of magical darkness, and the effect that created the darkness is of lower level than the gunlantern slug, the darkness is dispelled. If the magical darkness is higher level, the duration of the illumination effect ends.
trans-unit.target: If the wielder points their light into a region of magical darkness, and the effect that created the darkness is of lower level than the gunlantern slug, the darkness is dispelled. If the magical darkness is higher level, the duration of the illumination effect ends.

trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6

trans-unit.source: Form: Slug emits ghostly whispers
trans-unit.target: Form: Slug emits ghostly whispers

trans-unit.source: Effect: Whether the attack against the primary target hits (and deals damage normally) or misses, the bullet’s malignance isn’t spent—it attacks up to 3 additional targets within short range of the primary target. (The PC rolls an attack against each one.) Each additional attack successively increases the GM intrusion range by 1. If a GM intrusion is triggered, the haunted bullet hits something other than what the attacker intended, such as an ally.
trans-unit.target: Effect: Whether the attack against the primary target hits (and deals damage normally) or misses, the bullet’s malignance isn’t spent—it attacks up to 3 additional targets within short range of the primary target. If a GM intrusion is triggered, the haunted bullet hits something other than what the attacker intended, such as an ally.

trans-unit.source: Heavenly Fire Round
trans-unit.target: Heavenly Fire Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6

trans-unit.source: Form: Bullet emits a silvery glow
trans-unit.target: Form: Bullet emits a silvery glow

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. An attack with the round deals 1 additional point of damage on a successful attack (or 2 more if the cypher is level 5 or higher). If the same target is hit a total of three times by a heavenly fire round in the same minute, they are transformed into a pillar of salt, meaning they are effectively dead until alchemy or curse‑breaking magic is applied.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute. An attack with the round deals 1 additional point of damage on a successful attack (or 2 more if the cypher is level 5 or higher). If the same target is hit a total of three times by a heavenly fire round in the same minute, they are transformed into a pillar of salt, meaning they are effectively dead until alchemy or curse‑breaking magic is applied.

trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 1

trans-unit.source: Form: Bullet casing seems to burn with red flame
trans-unit.target: Form: Bullet casing seems to burn with red flame

trans-unit.source: Effect: A successful attack deals damage normally. In addition to potential damage from the initial attack, the bullet explodes in an immediate radius, inflicting fire damage equal to the cypher’s level (roll an attack against each creature in the area separately, including the initial target, who may or may not have already taken damage).
trans-unit.target: Effect: A successful attack deals damage normally. trans-unit.source: Hexing Round
trans-unit.target: Hexing Round

trans-unit.source: Level: 1d6 + 4
trans-unit.target: Level: 1d6 + 4

trans-unit.source: Form: “HEX” scribed on bullet case
trans-unit.target: Form: “HEX” scribed on bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute.
trans-unit.target: Effect: When this round is fired from a gun, additional attacks made from the gun gain the same benefit for the next minute.

trans-unit.source: A successful attack with a hexing round doesn’t damage the target; instead, a target whose level is equal to or less than the round’s level is hindered on all tasks. Additional successful attacks against the same target hinder their tasks by additional steps. If a target is struck by a number of hexing rounds equal to half or more of their level, they enter a “hexed” state for a number of days equal to the round’s level. A hexed target resembles someone sleepwalking who takes whatever suggestion is given them, even if that proves harmful. A hexed PC can attempt to break the enchantment once each day at dawn, and each time they’re damaged, by succeeding on an Intellect defense roll. NPCs whose level is higher than the cypher’s can break free a couple of days after they’re hexed, or sooner if they take damage.
trans-unit.target: A successful attack with a hexing round doesn’t damage the target; instead, a target whose level is equal to or less than the round’s level is hindered on all tasks. Additional successful attacks against the same target hinder their tasks by additional steps. If a target is struck by a number of hexing rounds equal to half or more of their level, they enter a “hexed” state for a number of days equal to the round’s level. A hexed target resembles someone sleepwalking who takes whatever suggestion is given them, even if that proves harmful. A hexed PC can attempt to break the enchantment once each day at dawn, and each time they’re damaged, by succeeding on an Intellect defense roll. NPCs whose level is higher than the cypher’s can break free a couple of days after they’re hexed, or sooner if they take damage.

trans-unit.target: Form: “INVULNERABLE” scribed on bullet case

trans-unit.source: Effect: Someone successfully attacked with the bullet gains a number of points of Armor equal to the cypher’s level for one minute. The Armor is effective against all forms of damage, including those that normally ignore Armor.
trans-unit.target: Effect: Someone successfully attacked with the bullet gains a number of points of Armor equal to the cypher’s level for one minute. The Armor is effective against all forms of damage, including those that normally ignore Armor.
